awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Implementing an integrated, wireless monitoring network to enhance decision making in communities impacted by environmental and industrial change
awd_abstract_narration:
Texas coastal communities have historically been exposed to environmental threats from natural and industrial sources. In Ingleside on the Bay (IOB), a small, rural community situated along the shoreline of Corpus Christi Bay, tropical storms and high rates of relative sea-level rise cause extreme and nuisance flooding, while industrial expansion is placing stress on the community’s way of life and the natural resources upon which it relies. Such communities lack the comprehensive data needed to advocate for and make informed decisions about risk reduction strategies to mitigate the impacts of industrial growth and climate change. This proposal engages with the nonprofit Ingleside on the Bay Coastal Watch Association (IOBCWA), community members, and governmental representatives to assess the role of distributed, real-time sensor technology in improving IOB’s capacity to respond to dynamic environmental conditions that affect the quality of its air, water, and land resources. It also examines how emerging community-based nonprofits like IOBCWA engage with diverse organizations in response to new threats and how they can utilize environmental sensing data in planning and advocacy efforts.

This project will leverage interdisciplinary, sociotechnical methods to (1) assess the current structure of communication and information-sharing networks related to environmental threats and mitigation planning in IOB; (2) activate academic-civic partnerships to deploy environmental monitoring sensors to generate a pilot smart grid for comprehensive and timely data collection; (3) develop a preliminary online data visualization dashboard that makes sensor data available in real-time to the community; and (4) assess how the data and dashboard can be utilized by residents and nonprofit organizations to inform sustainable planning and development strategies that address industrial permitting challenges and safeguard community and environmental well-being. To achieve the technical objectives, this project will develop and deploy a pilot sensing network for real-time environmental monitoring, design an online dashboard and data analysis framework to display the collected data in real-time, and beta test the dashboard among a diverse group of residents, community leaders, and local stakeholders. To achieve the social science objectives, this project will apply grounded theory to characterize the evolving role of community-based nonprofits in networking, civic engagement, and policymaking efforts in IOB and identify data needs that can be addressed by leveraging sensor technology to provide a scientific basis for decision-making. Community workshops will provide opportunities to refine the study needs and objectives, obtain feedback on the sensor network and dashboard, and co-develop a vision for future integrative research efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This planning grant applied a sociotechnical research approach to assess the role of distributed sensor technology in improving sustainable decision making in Ingleside on the Bay (IOB), Texas, a community threatened by human-induced climate change. The findings established that distributed, real-time sensor technology is viewed as a valuable tool in improving the ability of IOB and the broader Coastal Bend Region to respond to dynamic environmental conditions that affect the quality of their air, water, and land resources.

The project has contributed to social science research by analyzing how rural, community-based nonprofits develop planning and policy-making structures and build adaptive capacity in response to environmental threats. In particular, using a case study centered on the nonprofit Ingleside on the Bay Coastal Watch Association, we identified three criteria that should be strengthened to build adaptive capacity in the governing system: (1) improve formalization of assessments, plans, and policies practiced or desired at the local scale, (2) establish regional partnerships that can help create plans, place community champions in governing institutions, and forge formal inter-agency agreements to address environmental challenges, and (3) include socially vulnerable communities that are currently lacking representation in mitigation planning. These criteria cross the local to regional scales, highlighting the need to develop stronger regional integration within the Coastal Bend. Lessons from this study contribute to the understanding of small, rural nonprofit behavior, which has been understudied compared to larger and well-resourced nonprofit organizations.

From a technical perspective, this project has generated new protocols for developing a real-time, reliable, and secure sensor network in a harsh coastal environment. We have used our pilot sensor network as a testbed to identify and address real-world security issues related to the use and deployment of real-time data collection systems. We have also documented challenges related to the integration of new technologies into the existing social, cultural, and political fabric of communities. Such challenges include developing appropriate privacy protocols, establishing property access agreements for sensor placement, instilling a sense of ownership of the sensor network among residents, and training residents on the appropriate use and interpretation of the generated data, among others. These challenges are important to document because they can present serious limitations to the deployment of technology for real-world applications and must be addressed to enable the widespread adoption of smart and connected technologies that support community needs.

The project has led to the formation of a multidisciplinary partnership between technical and social science professionals from academia, government agencies, and community groups to enhance exposure to smart and connected technologies and advance the use of data in sustainable planning efforts aimed at improving community and environmental well-being. This partnership resulted in two-way learning between the academic team and the community. The project also enhanced public engagement with and knowledge of science and technology by including residents in (1) community workshops to identify challenges and map hot spots of environmental concern, (2) beta-testing efforts to learn to use and provide feedback on a real-time data dashboard, and (3) sensor maintenance and data collection efforts. In addition, the project has resulted in the creation of best practices for incorporating local knowledge and experiences into the development of environmental monitoring networks. This can contribute to the expanding field of community science by providing guidance for engaging non-scientific audiences and frontline communities in use-inspired research activities. Finally, the project has provided opportunities for three graduate students and one undergraduate student to engage in multidisciplinary environmental research, learn about community-engaged research practices, and lead the development of journal papers and conference presentations to share their research findings.
